questions.text: A child presents with intermittent jaundice and splenomegaly. There is a family history of similar symptoms in an older sibling. Peripheral blood smear findings are provided. What is the most appropriate diagnostic test to confirm this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing spherocytes most likely suggest a diagnosis of hereditary spherocytosis.

The osmotic fragility test is used to diagnose hereditary spherocytosis, as spherocytes are more fragile and lyse in hypotonic solutions.

  • Hereditary spherocytosis (HS) is an inherited disorder caused by intrinsic defects in the red cell membrane skeleton that render red cells spheroid, less deformable, and vulnerable to splenic sequestration and destruction.
  • It has an autosomal dominant inheritance(75%) characterised by ankyrin mutation and an autosomal recessive inheritance characterised by spectrin mutation.
  • The most specific morphologic finding is spherocytosis: Dark-staining (hyperchromic) spherocytes lacking the central zone of pallor.
  • Other features include reticulocytosis.
  • The characteristic clinical features are anaemia, splenomegaly, jaundice, and an increased risk of gallstones.
  • Severity ranges from asymptomatic to severe hemolytic anaemia requiring transfusions.
  • Early complications include neonatal jaundice and hemolytic crises.
  • Late complications include gallstones and, rarely, iron overload.

questions.text: An African child presents with a jaw mass. Biopsy of the lesion reveals the findings shown in the provided image. Cytogenetic analysis identifies a t(8;14) translocation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The "starry sky" appearance and t(8;14) translocation are characteristic of Burkitt lymphoma, a high-grade B-cell lymphoma.

  • The translocation involves the MYC gene on chromosome 8, leading to uncontrolled cell proliferation.
  • All forms of Burkitt's lymphoma (Endemic, Sporadic, and HIV associated) are associated with such translocations.
  • The most common translocations are t (8:2), t(8:14), and t(8:22)
  • Burkitt's lymphoma is a highly aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma associated with the translocations of the MYC gene on chromosome 8, t(8:14).
  • It has three primary subtypes:
    1. Endemic Burkitt's lymphoma: Commonly affects children in malaria-endemic areas of Africa, often presenting with tumours in the jaw or facial bones.
    2. Sporadic Burkitt's lymphoma: More frequently seen in non-endemic regions and usually involving the ileocaecal region and
    3. Immunodeficiency-associated Burkitt's lymphoma: Found in patients with conditions such as HIV/AIDS or other forms of immunodeficiency.

Key Takeaways:

Burkitt's lymphoma has three primary subtypes, and almost all cases of Burkitt lymphoma are latently infected with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)

  1. 100% of endemic cases
  2. 20% of sporadic cases
  3. 25% of HIV-associated cases

questions.text: A child presents with cola-colored urine, elevated blood pressure, and periorbital oedema. Laboratory investigations show a serum creatinine level of 2.5 mg/dL, which increases to 4.5 mg/dL over three weeks despite therapy. Based on this clinical course, which finding is most likely to be seen on electron microscopy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Subepithelial deposits are characteristic of PSGN in electron microscopy. 

  • The clinical presentation, including cola-coloured urine, hypertension, oedema, and rising creatinine levels, is highly suggestive of acute glomerulonephritis, particularly post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).

Explanation for other options:

Given the worsening renal function (rising creatinine levels) over time and the risk of progression to Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN), a finding of crescent formation (Option C) in the glomeruli would be expected, but it is a histopathological finding & not an electron microscope finding.

Subendothelial deposits (Option A) are typically seen in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN), not in post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).

Mesangial deposits (Option D) are often seen in conditions like IgA nephropathy, membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN), or diabetic nephropathy, but not typically in PSGN.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents with facial swelling, frothy urine, elevated blood pressure, and microscopic hematuria. He has a history of hepatitis B infection. Kidney biopsy shows a characteristic spike and dome appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The combination of frothy urine, hypertension, and the biopsy finding points to the diagnosis of Membranous nephropathy, which is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults.

  • It is often associated with hepatitis B and is characterised by the spike and dome pattern on kidney biopsy due to subepithelial immune complex deposition (primarily IgG and C3).

Membranous nephropathy:

  • M/C cause of nephrotic syndrome in elderly patients.
  • It is immune complex-mediated and can be caused by malignancy(colon, lung, melanoma), infections(malaria, hepatitis B, C, syphilis, schistosomiasis), drugs(gold, penicillamine), or autoimmune conditions(SLE).
  • In primary membranous nephropathy, antibodies primarily target the M-type phospholipase A2 receptor (PLA2R) located on the basal surface of podocytes. This triggers complement activation and subepithelial immune complex deposition, resembling Heymann nephritis lesions.
  • Other less common target antigens include THSD7A and neutral endopeptidase (CD10).
  • The presence of anti-PLA2R antibodies is crucial for diagnosing the disease.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with fever, fatigue, and signs of left ventricular dysfunction. An endomyocardial biopsy image is provided. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario of a child with complaints of fever, fatigue & LV dysfunction & biopsy showing lymphocytic infiltration is suggestive of Lymphocytic myocarditis, an inflammatory condition of the heart muscle characterised by the infiltration of lymphocytes, which are immune cells involved in viral or autoimmune responses.

  • Etiology:
    • Viral infections (e.g., enteroviruses, adenoviruses)
    • Postviral reactions
    • Autoimmune diseases (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis)
    • Idiopathic cases (unknown cause)
  • Pathological finding:
    • Lymphocytic infiltration: Predominantly, lymphocytes infiltrate the myocardium, especially in the left ventricle.
    • Myocyte necrosis: The inflammation leads to the death of myocardial cells.
    • Fibrosis: Chronic cases may develop fibrosis and scarring in the heart tissue.
    • Dilated cardiomyopathy: Severe cases can lead to heart enlargement and dysfunction.
  • Prognosis: The prognosis depends on the underlying cause, extent of myocardial damage, and response to treatment. Viral myocarditis can resolve with supportive care, but severe cases may lead to heart failure or require a heart transplant. Chronic forms may lead to dilated cardiomyopathy.

Reference:

  1. Acute lymphocytic myocarditis - PMC

questions.text: An elderly male with a history of smoking presents with chronic cough, marked weight loss, and fatigue. Laboratory tests show elevated serum calcium levels. Lung biopsy reveals large atypical cells with hyperchromatic nuclei. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

An elderly male smoker with chronic cough, weight loss, fatigue, and elevated serum calcium likely has squamous cell carcinoma of the lung.

  • This cancer is associated with paraneoplastic hypercalcemia due to PTHrP secretion. The biopsy showing large atypical cells with hyperchromasia supports this diagnosis.
  • Smoking significantly increases the risk of squamous cell carcinoma of the lung as it has a strong association, resulting in chromosomal deletions involving tumour suppressor loci involving 3p,9p and

Squamous cell carcinoma:

Squamous Cell Carcinoma is typically found in the central regions of the lungs (Not peripheral), often originating in the major bronchi near the hilum. It can cause symptoms by obstructing the airways. Histopathologically, it is characterised by keratin pearls, intercellular bridges, and nests of malignant squamous cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm.

Location of lung carcinomas:

  • Central: Squamous cell carcinoma, Small cell carcinoma, and Bronchial carcinoids.
  • Peripheral: Adenocarcinoma and Large-cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A young patient presents with a significant retroperitoneal haemorrhage and reports episodes of knee joint swelling following strenuous physical activity. There is no history of mucosal bleeding. Which coagulation factor deficiency is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient's symptoms (large retroperitoneal haemorrhage and knee swelling) suggest haemophilia, which is typically caused by deficiencies in Factor VIII (Haemophilia A) or Factor IX (Haemophilia B).

  • This condition is characterised by spontaneous or trauma-induced joint and muscle bleeds but not mucosal bleeding, which is distinct from von Willebrand disease or platelet dysfunction.
  • Haemophilia C is due to factor 11 deficiency, an autosomal recessive condition. Bleeding episodes are generally milder than in Haemophilia A and B.

Explanation for other options:

GP1b/IX (Option B): This is associated with Bernard-Soulier syndrome, a platelet disorder characterised by defective platelet adhesion. It leads to mucosal bleeding, which is absent in this case.

Von Willebrand factor (Option C) deficiency causes von Willebrand disease, which primarily results in mucosal bleeding (e.g., nosebleeds, gum bleeding) and not typically large retroperitoneal haemorrhages or joint bleeds.

Lupus anticoagulant (Option D): This is associated with antiphospholipid syndrome, leading to an increased risk of thrombosis (clots), not bleeding. It does not explain the bleeding symptoms described in this patient.

Key Takeaways:

questions.text: An elderly man presents for a routine check-up. Laboratory results reveal a markedly elevated total leukocyte count. Peripheral smear findings are shown in the provided image. What should be the next appropriate step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

An elderly male with a high total leukocyte count (TLC) and the presence of smudge cells on the peripheral smear is likely to have Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia (CLL).

The next appropriate step for confirming the diagnosis is flow cytometry, which analyses cell surface markers and helps identify abnormal lymphocytes characteristic of CLL.

Explanation for other options:

Stem cell transplantation (Option A): This is not the first-line treatment for CLL. It is typically considered in more advanced or refractory cases, but the initial approach for most patients involves observation or targeted therapy.

Bone marrow biopsy (Option B): Although bone marrow biopsy can help in finding the extent of infiltration, it is not the first choice for diagnosing CLL. Flow cytometry usually confirms the diagnosis, which is more specific for CLL.

High-dose chemotherapy (Option D) is generally not the first treatment for CLL. Most patients with early-stage CLL are observed without immediate chemotherapy. Treatment is usually initiated if there are symptoms or complications, and targeted therapies are often used instead of high-dose chemotherapy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with anaemia, thrombocytopenia (platelet count of 25,000/mL), gum bleeding, and prolonged PT and aPTT. A peripheral blood smear image is provided. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

AML with t(15;17) is characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukaemia (APML), which typically presents with Auer rods on the peripheral smear. The patient also exhibits typical features like low haemoglobin, low platelet count, gum bleeding, and prolonged PT and aPTT, which are seen in this condition due to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

M3 AML/ Acute promyelocytic leukaemia:

  • Genetics:
    • t(15:17) translocation causes PML-RARA (retinoic acid receptor alpha) fusion protein formation.
    • Blocks promyelocyte → myelocyte maturation.
    • Diagnosis of choice: Fluorescence In Situ Hybridisation (FISH)
  • Smear findings:
    • Increased promyelocytes.
    • Auer Rods: Fused granules in promyelocytes
    • Faggot Cells: Auer rods with a crisscross pattern.
  • Laboratory:
    • Low haemoglobin and platelets.
    • > 20% blasts on peripheral and bone marrow smear
    • Stain: PAS +
    • CD markers: CD 13, 33 +
  • Complication: Disseminated intravascular coagulation; therefore, chemotherapy is not recommended.
  • Treatment:
    • ATRA (All-trans-retinoic-acid) + As2O3 (arsenic trioxide)
    • Best prognosis among all AML.

questions.text: A chronic smoker with a 20-year history of working in a cement factory is diagnosed with mesothelioma. What is the most likely causative agent for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mesothelioma is primarily caused by exposure to asbestos fibres, which is a known risk factor for this type of cancer.

  • Long-term exposure to asbestos, especially in industries such as cement factories, is the most common occupational cause of mesothelioma.
  • Asbestos exposure is a well-established risk factor for developing laryngeal, ovarian, colon, lung, and pleural cancers.
  • Lung mesothelioma is a more specific tumour associated with asbestos exposure. It is common, but it is less prevalent than Adenocarcinoma.

Explanation for other options:

Silicosis (Option A) is caused by the inhalation of silica dust, commonly seen in industries such as mining and construction. While silica exposure can lead to lung fibrosis, it is not a direct cause of mesothelioma.

Coal worker pneumoconiosis (Option C), also known as black lung disease, results from the inhalation of coal dust. This condition affects the lungs but is not linked to mesothelioma.

Bagassosis (Option D) is caused by the inhalation of mouldy sugarcane dust and can lead to lung disease, but it is not associated with mesothelioma.

Key Takeaways:

  • Adenocarcinoma of the lung is the most common malignancy associated with asbestos exposure.
  • Mesothelioma is the most specific malignancy due to asbestos exposure.

Reference:

  1. Asbestosis - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: A patient received four units of blood transfusion two hours ago and now reports chest discomfort. A chest X-ray reveals bilateral fissure thickening. What is the most likely cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fluid overload is the most likely cause in this scenario. Transfusion of multiple units of blood, especially in a short period, can result in transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO), leading to symptoms like chest discomfort, shortness of breath, and bilateral fissure thickening on chest X-ray (indicative of pulmonary oedema).

Transfusion-Associated Circulatory Overload (TACO) is a common but often underrecognised complication of blood transfusions. It has become the leading cause of death related to transfusions since the risk of Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI) has decreased.

  • Risk factors:
    • Advanced age
    • Renal failure
    • Pre-existing fluid overload
    • Cardiac dysfunction
    • Administration of large blood volumes
    • Rapid transfusion rates relative to the patient's hemodynamic tolerance
  • Clinical presentation:
    • Dyspnea and hypoxia
    • Bilateral, predominantly alveolar infiltrates seen on chest X-ray
    • Frequent systolic hypertension
    • Elevated brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) levels
    • Fever (in some cases)
  • Prevention:
    • Identifying high-risk patients
    • Close monitoring during transfusion
    • Slowing the transfusion rate (e.g., administering 1 unit of red blood cells over 3-4 hours)
    • Using diuretics in hemodynamically stable patients with a history of TACO
  • Treatment:
    • Stopping the transfusion immediately
    • Administering oxygen
    • Administering diuretics to alleviate symptoms and prevent further complications.

Explanation for other options:

ABO incompatibility reaction (Option A) is a severe reaction that occurs immediately after transfusion and presents with hemolysis, fever, chills, and dark urine rather than chest discomfort or pulmonary findings like bilateral fissure thickening.

Hypocalcemia (Option C) can occur after rapid blood transfusions due to the citrate in blood products, which binds calcium. However, hypocalcemia typically presents with symptoms like tetany, paresthesias, or cardiac arrhythmias rather than chest discomfort and lung findings on X-ray.

Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) (Option D) is a rare but serious complication of blood transfusions, primarily in immunocompromised patients. It presents with skin rash, liver dysfunction, and gastrointestinal symptoms rather than chest discomfort or pulmonary oedema on X-ray.

choices.text: 2/3rd of Mendelian disorders are autosomal dominant
1/3rd of Mendelian disorders are autosomal recessive
Every 5th patient has an X-linked recessive disorder
Every 10th patient has a Y-linked disorder

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes a Mendelian pattern of inheritance?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Approximately 65% of human monogenic disorders are autosomal dominant, making this the most common Mendelian inheritance pattern.

Mendelian Disorders: (Classical inheritance)

  • Autosomal dominant
  • Autosomal recessive
  • X-linked dominant
  • X-linked recessive
  • Y-linked are extremely rare, and prevalence is much lower than 1/10.
